EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1. MARKET OVERVIEW


Influencer Market Insights

World Market Trajectories

Impact of Covid-19 and a Looming Global Recession

An Introduction to Digital Banking

Digital banking refers to the end-to-end digitization of a bank and all its activities, functions and programs, right from product development through to customer service. Digital banking not only involves digitizing the services and products of a bank at front- but also entails automating the banking processes at the back-end and connecting the front-end and back-end silos with proper middleware. Digital banking therefore emphasizes a complete transformation to a digital environment, including front-end and back-end and everything in between, at both bank customer as well as employee level. In the digital bank ecosystem, web based platforms functioning along with process automation tools and cross institutional service embedded with APIs, strive to deliver complete line of banking solutions and carry out online transactions in a seamless and cohesive manner. To ensure a comprehensive workflow and to improve and enhance the customer’s experience, the digital bank environment embraces all the new technologies including big data, Artificial Intelligence (AI), Machine Learning (ML), Natural Language Processing (NLP) and analytics. Digital banking offers numerous benefits to banking entities as well as banking customers. Key benefits offered by digital banking include cost savings, increased accuracy, business efficiency, greater agility, improved competitiveness, and enhanced security.

Invalidating the need for visiting a bank branch, digital banking allows banking customers carry out various banking transactions in digital mode. Money deposits, withdrawals, & transfers; checking/management of saving accounts; applying for banking products; loan management; bill payment; and account services are some banking activities that can be seamlessly executed by digital banking tools. Although, digital banking primarily focuses on remote deposits, money transfers, bill pay, and basic online account management, the technology also aims to improve customer experience in banking operations. Banking customers are bestowed with the capability to access their bank accounts through desktop PC, laptop, or mobile device or even the bank ATM.

Based on banking entity type, market for Digital Banking can be segregated into Retail Banking, Corporate Banking, and Investment Banking. Based on Solution, the market can be categorized into Payments, Processing Services, Customer & Channel Management, and Risk Management. By type of technology, the market can be grouped into Cloud-Based solutions, Banking as a Service (BaaS), Banking as a Platform (BaaP), White Label Banking, and Chatbots.


Digital Banking: Current Market Scenario and Outlook

World market for digital banking technologies grew considerably during the previous decade in line with substantial expansion in digital networks and penetration of Internet and Internet-connected devices such as computers and smartphones. Demand for various digital banking solutions such as Payment Tools, Processing Services, Customer & Channel Management platforms, and Risk Management solutions, among others, grew at a steady pace. Of various categories, sustained demand for Payment Tools and Processing Services, which currently account for a collective share of over 60% of total market revenues, has elevated the market prospects in a major way. Payment solutions constitute the largest category, representing about 36% share of total revenues estimated for digital banking market. Exhibiting a CAGR of 12.2% over the analysis period 2018-2025, Payment solutions segment is projected to reach US$7 billion by 2025 from an estimated US$3.5 billion in 2019. On the other hand, Processing Services represents the second major and the fastest growing category, trailing at a CAGR of 18.7% over the review period 2018-2025. Market for Processing Services is estimated at US$2.5 billion and is projected to reach US$7 billion by 2025. On the other hand, Customer & Channel Management segment is estimated at US$1.7 billion in 2019 and is projected to reach US$3.8 billion by 2025, demonstrating a CAGR of 14.7% over the analysis period. Similarly, Risk Management segment, offering digital security tools among others, is projected to reach US$3.2 billion by 2025 from an estimated US$1.3 billion by 2019, exhibiting a CAGR of 16.2% over the review period.

Uptake of digital banking solutions made a steady progress across various banking systems including retail, corporate and investment banking. Currently, Retail Banking constitutes the largest segment, representing 51% share of total market, equivalent to US$5 billion. Exhibiting a CAGR of 14% over the review period 2018-2025, digital banking revenues in retail banking domain are likely to exceed US$10.8 billion by 2025. On the other hand, Corporate Banking constitutes the fastest growing category. Demonstrating a CAGR of 18.1% over the review period, deployment of digital banking solutions in corporate banking sector is projected to surpass US$7.2 billion by 2025 from an estimated US$2.7 billion in 2019.

Growth momentum in the digital banking market is poised to remain strongly upward through the current decade in tandem with ongoing digitization trends in the banking & financial services sector. Factors such as integration of advanced technologies into the banking system, massive expansion in internet penetration and smartphone adoption, fast evolving relevance of online and mobile banking platforms, and soaring need to improve customer experience strategies are expected to provide fertile environment for market expansion. Supportive government initiatives and policies and emergence of new and innovative technologies on an ongoing basis constitute other major drivers for the market. A growing number of banking & financial service firms are moving towards digital platforms to offer their services acknowledging the high penetration rate of internet and Internet-connected devices such as smartphones. The rapidly increasing speed, bandwidth, storage capacity and on-demand computing capabilities offered by the Internet is fueling banking entities to shift towards online business models, emphasizing  transactions and payments through debit and credit cards and third party providers such as PayPal. With mobile Internet services providing access to various online portals and banking apps on-the-go, customers are now able to access online banking portals and make instantaneous transactions through online banking and debit/credit card credentials. At the same time, intense pressure on banking firms to minimize operating costs in order to stay competitive is also having a major bearing on uptake of digital banking solutions.

Digital banking continues to gain traction among banking firms by enabling them to keep systems up-to-date, offer modified services at minimal costs and an improved customer experience. Banking entities are also leaning towards digital solutions amid rapidly rising demand for non-transactional services due to the ease of operation and cost-effectiveness of such services. On the other hand, increased willingness among consumers, especially the younger demographics who are choice conscious, hyper connected, and has digital knowledge to take up the digital technology enabled services is encouraging banking firms to adopt the digital solutions. Adoption of digital banking services by Millennials and Gen Z customers is fueling growth of the overall market.

Although the prospects for digital banking market remain promising, certain issues and challenges continue to niggle the momentum. Concerns over cyber-attacks, data security, and data privacy, lack of awareness among consumers, and passive uptake by older demographics are some of the issues hampering the market prospects.


Analysis by Technology Type

Cloud-Based Solutions: Largest & Fastest Growing Technology Type

Cloud-based solutions constitute the largest and also the fastest growing technology type within the digital banking market. Demonstrating a CAGR of 17.0% over the review period 2018-2025, Cloud-based solutions segment is projected to reach US$12 billion by 2025 from an estimated US$US$4.7 billion in 2019. Share of the segment is projected to swell to 54% by 2025 from an estimated 47% in 2019. Cloud software (SaaS) has emerged as the new information and communications technology (ICT) frontier for banking & financial services firms, supported by varied benefits such as zero upfront costs towards outright purchase, functional convenience, and maintenance-free operation, quite contrast to on-premises software solutions. As the cloud-based software invalidates the need for procuring and deploying on-premises solutions for supporting various banking applications, the cloud model drastically decreases the costs that are otherwise needed for bringing in on-premises resources and infrastructure. Cost benefits associated with cloud-based software have a major bearing on the market adoption of these solutions. As cloud solution is offered in simple, pay-per-use, and per user pricing models without any additional or hidden costs, while drastically decreasing the management and maintenance costs, a growing number of banking & financial services firms are prioritizing the model in place of relatively expensive, maintenance-intensive on-premises platforms.

On-Premises Vs. Cloud-based Software: A Cost Comparison Analysis

Cost Parameter

On-Premise Software

Cloud-based Software

Plus Points for Cloud Solution

Upfront Implementation Costs

High

Low

No upfront licensing fee & no related purchases

Software & Other Infrastructure Costs

High

Not Applicable

Software/Hardware/Infrastructure is not required as all these are made available by cloud service provider

Maintenance Costs

Medium

Low or Not Applicable

No need for maintenance, as maintenance is handled by cloud service provider

Baas & BaaP Emerge to Drive Next Wave of Growth in Digital Banking

Banking as a Service (BaaS) and Banking as a Platform (BaaP), which collectively account for an estimated 34% share of total digital banking revenues, have emerged in the market offering top-of-class platforms for banking entities. BaaS and BaaP platforms are poised to make strong gains over the analysis period, thereby driving overall momentum in the digital banking market. BaaS strives to address the need to adjust the essence of the banking operation from maintaining a pricing policy based on liabilities and assets to brokering and providing attractive value-added services for customers on an ongoing basis. For banking operations, BaaS typically ensures anywhere, anytime access to account holders at optimum level. On the other hand, BaaP is focused more on aiding banks distribute their own products, and also those of third parties, through front-ends and Open APIs, such that account holders can seamlessly exchange information with multiple vendors.


White Label Banking: Niche Segment

White label banking constitutes a niche segment, representing an estimated 10% share of total digital banking market. White label banking enables fintech firms and third party entities to showcase a trimmed-down, company-branded front-end, while leveraging the license, technology, and regulatory compliance on the backend of an established bank to provide core banking features that rival major institutions. Some of the commonly deployed white label banking services are savings & checking accounts, current accounts, online payment transfer systems, simplified bill payments, debit/credit cards, personal loans, insurance, mortgages, periodic bank statements, and balance notifications. White label banking primarily aims to enable new companies to offer financial services which enhance their offering by using products from a white label supplier.


Chatbots Seek Prominent Role

Representing simple form of personal assistants in use, chatbots are becoming more intelligent and sophisticated with the addition of advanced functions. By definition, chatbots are computer programs that are engineered in a manner to conduct conversations with human being using a messaging interface. Led by various advancements such as machine learning, chatbots have evolved as an important part of customer service operations of businesses. Leveraging AI and data analysis, these systems are anticipated to understand consumer behavior, identify relevant patterns and learn personal choices to deliver enhanced service. AI powered chatbots today aid businesses address diverse problems, convey personalized messages and handle complex human interaction with ease.  These chatbots are being increasingly used in banking and financial industries. Banking firms and fintech companies are expected to increasingly utilize AI-driven chatbots, which can intelligently respond to customer queries and reduce load on the companies’ customer service employees. Based on predictive analytics, chatbots can anticipate customer queries and provide guidance. Bank of America AI-powered digital assistant Erica, for instance,  offers assistance to customers over their mobile phones for transactions including balance enquiries and offers personalized, proactive guidance to maintain their finances. Fintech companies are also integrating chatbots with social networking sites. AI-powered chatbots  are ideal for applications beyond communications, such as for taking orders from social networking sites, for checking and editing bank accounts, monitoring credit score, sending alerts to consumers about payments to be made and helping them in creating more realistic budgets among others.

Chatbots are smart programmed tools that invalidate the need for customer care executive in certain simple interactions with clients. Chatbots, designed for banking & financial services firms, are faster and work tirelessly on a 24x7x365 basis. Chatbots typically free up the customer support representative time by resolving basic queries, thereby allowing customer care executive to concentrate on the complex tasks. Chatbots can deliver considerable cost savings while improving the experience of clients. Although Chatbots offer considerable benefits, these tools are associate themselves with certain limitations. Inability to handle multiple languages and dialects, lack empathy in communication, prone to failure, and low retention rate are some of the limitations with Chatbots.


Competitive Scenario

Major Players in the Digital Banking Market

Digital banking market enjoys active participation of leading digital enterprise solutions vendors. Europe-based firms such as Temenos Group AG (Switzerland), SAP AG (Germany), Appway AG (Switzerland), Backbase (Netherlands), Fidor Solutions AG (Germany), NETinfo PLC (Cyprus), and NF Innova (Austria) enjoy considerable presence in the market. On the other hand, American companies such as Oracle Corporation, Fiserv Inc., and Technisys also have sizeable footprint in the market. Other major players include Tata Consultancy Services (TCS) and EdgeVerve Systems.

Viva Wallet, a cloud-based payments processor, has acquired Greece’s first digital challenger Praxia Bank following worries the neobank would dissolve due to a lack of sufficient funds.

The new service, Sesame Cash, has many features found in other challenger banking apps, like a general lack of fees, real-time notifications, an early payday option, free access to a sizable ATM network, in-app debit card management and more.

Aion introduces its signature product MoneyMax™, which is designed to help members maximise their money by earning more on their savings, saving more on their household bills and spending less on their online purchases.

Path Solutions has revealed its new Intelligent Digital initiative roadmap with the launch of Path Digital and Path Intelligence platforms which will enable forward-thinking banks to maintain competitive advantage by providing their customers with a consistent and seamless intelligent digital banking experience while harnessing the full potential of data.

2. FOCUS ON SELECT PLAYERS


Appway AG (Switzerland)

Appway AG is the globally leading innovative developer of software and technologies for financial services institutions through digital platforms. Product portfolio of the company includes agile development, boundless orchestration, cross-channel experience, reusable components and work automation. The solutions offered by the company comprise appway for insurance, digital banking platform, digital mortgage, KYC and regulatory reviews, onboarding for wealth and onboarding for retail. Appway’s digital banking platform provides digital transformation through intelligent process orchestration and interaction which enables digital world. The company’s trusted customers are located across the world such as BNY Mellon, Burgundy, J.P.Morgon, HSBC, and Credit Suisse among others.

Appway operates globally through US, Canada, Singapore, Hong Kong and headquartered in Geneva, Switzerland.


Backbase (Netherlands)

Backbase is the leading fintech software provider for financial institutions to become digital-first. The company’s digital-first solutions include corporate banking, retail banking, SME banking and wealth management. The company offers digital-first banking platform offers cloud deployment layer, digital banking layer, experience management layer, identity & entitlements layer and onboarding & origination layer to design, digitize and prevent cloud technology. Backbase digital banking platform deploys superior Banking-as-a-Platform capabilities with state-of-the-art microservices and API-based banking. The company’s services comprise backbase academy, professional services and product maintenance and support.

Backbase is headquartered in Amsterdam, The Netherlands and operates across Canada, US, UK and EMEA.


EdgeVerve Systems Limited (India)

EdgeVerve Systems Limited, a subsidiary of Infosys, develops software products for on premise and cloud-hosted business platforms. The products of the company include automation, AI platform, AI business application and banking. EdgeVerve Systems products find use in retail and CPG, insurance, life sciences, manufacturing, telecommunications and financial services. The company’s banking solution developed Finacle, an industry-leading digital banking solution suite for frictionless customer experiences, larger ecosystem play, insights–driven interactions and ubiquitous automation. EdgeVerve Systems Finacle solution addresses requirements of  corporate banking, capital markets, credit union, community banking, wealth banking, islamic banking, universal banking, retail banking, small finance bank and payments bank.

Founded in 2014, EdgeVerve Systems Limited is headquartered in Karnataka, India.


Fidor Solutions AG (Germany)

Fidor Solutions AG is the leader in designing, building and marketing of digital platforms for financial, retail and telecom institutions. The company designed fidorOS, a cutting-edge digital platform APIs for next generation of banking. The solutions offered by the company include API & sandbox, bank as a service, banking on community, bank as a platform, marketplace and payment as a service. Fidor developed digital banking accelerator for modern-day banking and uses state-of-the-art technology, such as RESTful with JSON data sets and OAuth authentication. The company markets its platform with APIs and Sandbox with benefits such as core banking agnostic, on premises, SaaS, AWS or private cloud, off-the-shelf banking products, licensing or pay as you grow and open API for easy integration to become a digital bank.

Fidor Solutions is headquartered in Munich, Germany. The company offices are also located in Berlin, Singapore and Dubai.


Fiserv, Inc. (USA)

Fiserv, Inc., is one of the leading fintech and payments financial services company. The solutions offered by the company includes customer & channel management, payments, processing services, insights & optimization and risk & compliance for associations, billers, banks, business banking, corporate services, credit unions, government, de novos, institutional asset management, lending, healthcare, property management, telecommunications, thrifts, insurance and utilities among others. The company’s customer & channel management enables online banking solutions to manage user access, transactions and accessing electronic statements for individuals, families, small businesses or corporations.

Founded in 1984, Fiserv is headquartered in Wisconsin, US.


NETinfo PLC (Cyprus)

NETinfo PLC is the leading innovative technology company for banks and financial institutions. The company possesses expertise in retail banking, corporate banking, wealth management, and insurance. The products of the company include NETinfo Digital Banking Platform and NETinfo Mobile Financial Services (MFS). The company’s NETinfo Digital Banking Platform is a comprehensive suite of digital banking needs with functionalities and features for financial institutions. The digital platform offers solution for ATM,     kiosk, wearables, digital wallet, open banking, internet banking, mobile banking, alerts & notifications, social media banking, chatbot and call center. The company’s digital platform provides 360 dashboard view, transfers and payments, NETinfo open banking suite and other features such as administration module, corporate functionality, customer experience, onboarding, personal financial management (PFM), one installation, many banks, authentication suite, publishing new digital services: self-service.

Founded in 2000, NETinfo Plc is headquartered in Nicosia, Cyprus.


NF Innova (Austria)

NF Innova, based in Austria is a leading developer of software for financial markets. The solutions of the company include digital branch (online banking platform), dual brand (online brand for smart platform), white label (banking solution for non-financial institutions) and partner ecosystem (online business platform). The platform offered by the company comprises single digital platform for reliable banking services through web, mobile phone, tablet, smart watch, contact center, kiosk, SMS and among others. The company includes iBanking, a true omni-channel, state-of-the-art digital core middleware banking solution provides unique platform for various channels. The company also offers mobile onboarding application for banks to provide simple access to next generation banking solutions.


Oracle Corporation (USA)

Oracle Corporation is one of the leading Information Technology (IT) companies specializing in developing enterprise software products, database management systems and IT hardware solutions. Oracle is a dominant force in database software and technology, enterprise software, and cloud engineered systems, and has huge reputation for its ERP, CRM, and SCM software products. Oracle develops and delivers middleware, database and application software to provide end-to-end IT capabilities to enterprises across industries. Oracle’s portfolio includes enterprise management solutions, engineered systems, storage servers, data center and networking–related products, operating systems, databases and applications. Along with conventional IT solutions, Oracle also focuses on emerging and next generation IT disciplines including AI, IoT, machine learning, and blockchain, among others.

Oracle’s financial services include banking products such as retail banking, corporate banking, payments, universal banking, specialty lending and investor servicing. The company offers oracle banking digital experience solution, a highly customizable, context-aware, omnichannel digital experience solution for new age customers. Oracle Banking Digital Experience is an enterprise-class, open, cloud-ready, scalable, digital banking solution for retail, SME, corporate, and Islamic businesses. Select features of the product consists of digital banking for corporates of any size, manage complexity with virtual accounts, user-friendly originations, advanced customer engagement and highly personalized retail servicing among others.

Oracle, established in 1977, is based out of Redwood City, California, US, and has offices and R&D centers in several parts of the world.


SAP AG (Germany)

SAP SE, headquartered in Walldorf, Germany, is a leading developer and provider of enterprise application software solutions. A highly distinguished vendor of Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP), SAP also holds industry-proven expertise in CRM, HCM, PLM, SCM, Analytics, Content & Collaboration, Data Management, Financial Management, and Supplier Relationship Management domains.

SAP solutions for banking include integrated applications, intelligent technologies, and a digital platform to support financial markets. Select features of the product include banking operations, digital customer engagement, financial services networks, finance & risk and total spend management. The company also offers mobile banking apps, omnichannel banking, and digital banking analytics such as SAP Omnichannel Banking and SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

SAP’s digital customer engagement provides omnichannel commerce management, optimized marketing, omnichannel customer service and digital banking self-services among several others.

SAP digital banking includes integrated digital banking service such as SAP® Model Company which offers business processes and capabilities (deposit and loans management, collateral management, finance and payments and cross-functions), delivery approach (preconfigured solution and business content and accelerators) and applications (SAP S/4HANA® 1610, banking services from SAP 9.0 and SAP payment engine 8.0).

Established in 1972, SAP manages operations in more than 190 countries across the world.


Tata Consultancy Services Limited (India)

Tata Consultancy Services Limited (TCS), part of Tata Group, is one of the largest global IT services company and is the leading provider of BPO services and solutions. The company offers services to varied industries including banking & financial, health care & life sciences, travel & hospitality, retail & consumer packaged goods, and telecom. TCS offers consultation services has a workforce of over 417,000 people in 46 countries.

TCS BaNCS is a core banking software suite developed to help financial services and institutions for digital customer engagement. TCS banking products include TCS BaNCS Digital, TCS BaNCS Cloud, BaNCS ADK and TCS OPTiX. The company’s TCS BaNCS Digital offers a consistent and integrated digital banking to manage finances. The solution is a responsive web design and hybrid architecture coupled with sumer and enterprise apps, social media and real-time analytics. The components of the product includes BaNCS ADK (Application Development Kit), digital online account opening, retail banking, Small and Medium Businesses (SMBs) and Analytics and Insights for Enterprises. The company’s product finds use in corporate loan origination, community banks, compliance, FATCA compliance, treasury, global banking platform, payments, islamic banking, global risk management, reconciliations, online account opening and wealth management.


Technisys (USA)

Technisys is the digital banking technology company. The company’s omnichannel and digital core solutions transform traditional banks to digital. Technisys Cyberbank Digital offers Cyberbank Cloud to create digital banks from scratch. The company’s solutions include Banking Software – Cyberbank Core and Digital banking – Cyberbank Digital.

The Cyberbank digital platform delivers customized and multisegment financial services. The platform offers solutions through ATMs, branches, call centers, kiosks, tablets, web, mobile, smart TVs and social networks. Cyberbank Digital is integrated with Cyberbank Core’s platform.

Founded in 1995, Technisys is headquartered in  Florida, US.


Temenos Group AG (Switzerland)

Temenos Group AG is engaged in developing enterprise software for banks and financial services. The products of the company include front-to-back banking software such as temenos infinity – digital front office, temenos transact – core banking, temenos payments, temenos infinity wealth, temenos fund administration, temenos data & analytics, temenos country model banks, temenos financial crime mitigation, temenos regulatory compliance and temenos quantum – multiexperience development platform. The company’s solutions comprises corporate banking, retail banking, fund management, universal banks, wealth management & private banking, small business banking, islamic banking, challenger banks and among several other sectors. Temenos products offers end-to-end banking solutions delivered with advanced cloud-native, cloud-agnostic, AI and API-first Temenos Platform deployed on premise, in the cloud and as a service.

Temenos Infinity – Digital Front Office consists of distribution services, customer acquisition, onboarding & origination, omnichannel banking, client servicing, customer retention & marketing and robo-advisor. The company delivers Temenos SaaS, market-leading, compliant and highly secured, functionally rich banking software.

Founded in 1993, Temenos Group AG is headquartered in Geneva, Switzerland.


3. MARKET TRENDS & DRIVERS


In This Age of Digitalization, Digital Banking Acquires Significance

The role of digitalization in business and consumer sectors is becoming increasingly bigger. The importance of digitization and digitalization can be put into perspective by the fact that inability to keep with them has the potential to jeopardize the very survival of businesses. Digitalization is defined as the use of digital technologies to transform business models in a manner that enables new value creation opportunities and opens up new revenue avenues for companies.  Digitalization is longer an option for businesses but a necessity to compete in a changing world increasingly underscored by tough economic fundamentals. Benefits of well-executed digitalization for businesses include operational efficiency offered by automating manual and paper based processes; elimination of redundancies; a more efficient communications chain; reduced risk of human error; better ability to utilize information and data already available; ability to take advantage of analytics to improve business and process insights; improved business continuity; enhanced efficiency of all enterprise processes; higher flexibility and agility to respond to dynamic market changes; improve access to better and more timely information exchange between all departments in an enterprise; better quality of products and services offered and delivering higher value to customers. The ability to operate faster, better and cheaper will give companies a competitive advantage in the market which is ultimate goal of all companies. Digital transformation will also make consumption of energy and resources more efficient and sustainability. Virtually all businesses have embraced digitization and have begun the journey of digital transformation. Billions of dollars are being injected into the transformation process opening up attractive opportunities for myriad allied markets that encompass semiconductors, hardware, software, cloud services, and platform providers, among others. Technologies at the forefront of this digital transformation include cloud computing, Internet of Things (IoT), Big Data, Data Analytics, Artificial Intelligence, Mobility/Social Media, Cybersecurity, 3D Printing, and Wearable Technology. Top industries at the forefront of digitalization include banking & financial services, health & pharma, automotive, process & discrete manufacturing, oil & gas, telecom and finance. Banks & financial services firms, because of their customer-centric approach and to address the need to resolve ever-growing workload, have emerged as a core sector steering the digitalization drive. With retail, corporate and investor banking environments intending to roll out full-fledged digital banking platforms in tune with the ongoing digitalization drive, demand for digital banking platforms including Cloud-Based, BaaS, BaaP, White Label Banking, and Chatbots is poised to grow considerably in the coming years.


EXHIBIT: Global Digital Transformation Opportunity (In US$ Billion) for the Years 2019, 2021 and 2023
Year Market Size (US$ Billion)
2019 318.6
2021 436.4
2023 619.5

*Figures pertain to investments in disruptive digital technologies such as Cloud Computing, Big Data & Analytics, Mobility/Social Media, Cybersecurity, and Artificial Intelligence.


The Healthy Internet Economy Creates Fertile Ground for Digital Banking Market

The phenomenal evolutionary leap made by the Internet will continue to wield a far reaching impact on civil societies and businesses. Launch of new generation converged communication services including high speed data services, convergence of voice and data, expanding 3G/4G mobile network deployments represent factors driving rapid growth in broadband Internet penetration. Also, flat rate pricing has eliminated cost barriers and enabled greater access to Internet and related services. Another key development shaping the next generation Internet economy is the rapidly growing Internet connection, download and upload speeds. The migration to fiber networks, development of innovative technologies that boost speeds over fiber (i.e. SDM or WDM (spatial and wavelength-division multiplexing), advancements in next-generation passive optical networks, rise of commercial single-laser-single-fiber network connections, are all playing instrumental roles in the creation of super high-speed Internet infrastructure. Disruptive technologies such as cloud computing and Internet of Things (IoT) are additionally catalyzing the evolution of Internet speeds.

Governments and business communities are investing in Internet technologies to improve their chances of succeeding in the digitalized global economy. Continuously increasing speed of the Internet that facilitates immediate and faster connectivity and the flexibility to utilize and leverage bandwidth intensive data, is also cited as another key factor driving up penetration of broadband Internet. Faster transmission speeds enables easy and quick transfer of content. The deployment of ultra-high bandwidth networks like LTE, Advanced LTE and WiMAX therefore works in favor of IPAM. The market stands to especially benefit from 4G networks as 4G technologies such as WiMAX and LTE delivers higher transmission capacity than 3G wireless networks. Capable of enabling wireless data, voice and video transmission with high rate of transmission in the fixed and mobile environments, 4G technologies are already being heralded as the future of telecommunications. The Internet’s continuously increasing speed, bandwidth, storage capacity, and on-demand computing power will drive use of the Internet for conducting financial transactions. A growing number of companies including traditional service providers like utilities are increasingly migrating to an online business model where customers are allowed to make their payments through credit cards and/or third-party services, such as PayPal. As individuals and businesses switch to electronic methods of banking, the market for digital banking is poised to witness robust growth in the coming years.


EXHIBIT: Global Internet Users in Billion for the Years 2014 through 2020
Year Internet Users (in Billion)
2014 3.0
2015 3.3
2016 3.5
2017 3.8
2018 4.0
2019 4.2
2020 4.6


Increasing Use of Smartphones Encourages Adoption of Digital Banking

Mobile Internet access is one of the prime drivers for digital banking. Providing users a direct and easy on-the go access to company, bank or even government department’s payment portals over a mobile browser, the use of mobile Internet has been on the rise since its introduction. With the advent of mobile Internet facility it is today possible to access banking information even on mobile devices, through online portals as well as mobile apps of banking entities. Thanks to the introduction of mobile Internet, users not only gained access to a range of online payment options such as online bank transfer, debit card and credit card payment, but also have the opportunity to check-out their latest bank statements, bank transactions and bills mailed to their e-mail account on the move. With the mobile revolution sweeping the world, it is now possible to present the summary of banking transactions on even feature phones, while the advent of advanced mobile devices mobile devices such as smartphones and tablets, essentially have taken it to the next level. With availability of debit card, credit card and even direct debit & online bank transfers it is today possible to make banking transactions, instantly.

One of the main factors driving the phenomenal success of smartphones across the globe is the versatility of the device. Combining the functionalities of mobile phones with the computing ability of PDAs and laptops, smartphones have struck the right chord among people in all walks of life. A smartphone can be a PDA, a laptop, an entertainment/multimedia system, a navigation device, contactless wallet, a barcode reader, a social networking/email client, and a mobile phone, all rolled into one. Unlike the traditional mobile phones that only support voice & text based communications, smartphones are also capable of running high-end applications such as the mobile Internet browsing, mobile email, Bluetooth, real time GPS navigation, video calls, document reader, and multi-media entertainment applications. Capable of connecting to corporate network, smartphones are also being increasingly pursued by corporate executives as business tools that can help them gain access to company network, and carry out necessary business transactions from the convenience of their mobile phones. Expanding enterprise mobile applications such as enterprise email, desktop/mobile integration, CRM, mobile commerce, telematics and tracking are additionally driving adoption of smartphones. Smitten by the ability of smartphones to accelerate business transactions, support workforce mobility, and enhance employee/enterprise productivity, business organizations across the globe are increasingly allowing the use of smartphones by their employees and are even willing to reimburse the costs by treating them as a business expense.

Spiraling global sales of smartphones coupled with widespread consumer acceptance of Mobile value added services (M-VAS), such as, Mobile Internet browsing, mobile games, mobile social networking, mobile music, mobile payments, mobile wallet, mobile learning, and mobile Location-Based-Services (LBS), bode well for digital banking through mobile phones. Improvements in quality of service, ease of configuration and provisioning, development of MVAS ecosystem (comprising content aggregators, providers, and distributors), proliferation of handsets capable of supporting MVAS, and ratification of MVAS standards, among others, represent factors which are encouraging digital banking through mobile phones. Huge population, rising disposable incomes, growing consumer affluence, improving broadband penetration, high use of Internet, strong penetration of advanced mobile devices in countries such as China, Korea and India make Asia-Pacific a market laden with tremendous potential for digital banking market. Enormous growth in adoption of 4G enabled smartphones, expanding deployment of 4G networks, and subsequent rise in number of people accessing online multimedia content over mobile handsets are also boosting market prospects for mobile-enabled digital banking. Developments in smartphone security software also represent another major factor encouraging the use of smartphone for digital banking. Market opportunities in this space are further supported by easy availability of reliable software for preventing unwarranted tracking of users via GPS or installed spyware, identifying stealth monitoring software that spy on users personal data and blocking financial malware, which allows offenders to steal personal financial information such as credit card or online banking data.


EXHIBIT: Smartphone Users as % of Global Population for the Period 2018-2022
Year 2018 2019 2020 2021 2022
Smartphone Users as % of Global Population 35.1 37.3 39.6 41.5 43.7


Rapid 4G LTE Penetration Provides the Platform for Future Growth

Currently, the more advanced 4th generation (4G) technology is gaining ground in the mobile communication space, while totally outpacing the 3G technology. 4G networks can typically provide 300 Mbps downlink peak data rates with 20+20 MHz bandwidth in the LTE version, which can be improved to more than 1 Gbps with latest LTE-Advanced (LTE-A) technology through methods such as higher-order modulation, 4X4 MIMO and carrier aggregation. Similarly, LTE networks provide 71 Mbps uplink peak data rates with 20+20 MHz bandwidth, which can be improved to about 1 Gbps with LTE-A technology. 4G technology, based on LTE Advanced (LTE-A) of 3GPP and IEEE 802.16m (Mobile WiMAX Release 2) specifications as per IMT-Advanced standards, is a more refined and much faster mobile network service, capable of meeting the myriad mobile communication needs of modern population. In line with growing demand for additional capacity from mobile subscribers, MNOs are leaning towards 4G technology, to leverage the high spectral efficiency, low latency, and high data throughput benefits offered by the technology. 4G comes with a flat architecture with very few nodes in the core network and a low transmission-time interval (TTI) of 1 millisecond, to produce lowest latency than any existing mobile technology. Leveraging novel radios and antennas, 4G enables highly convenient MIMO deployment, while invalidating the logistical challenges associated with adding new antennas to MIMO equipment in legacy technologies. Further, 4G can be conveniently deployed in wide radio channels with carrier aggregation of up to 640 MHz to significantly increase peak data rates and for efficient use of spectrum. The new network technology standard marks a paradigm shift in enabling high speed Internet accessibility on mobile devices, unlocking a range of business opportunities around it. High bandwidth capacity and speeds makes it possible to conduct business over the mobile phones and even run high bandwidth apps such as bank apps and payment apps (PayPal).


Developments in Mobile Wallet & Payment Apps Bode Well

Mobile wallets have transformed the way people shop and make payments for various goods or services. The concept revolves around using mobile phones for making payments or transferring money. Mobile wallets are presently exhibiting increased adoption across the globe. In the coming years, the global mobile wallet market is expected to witness remarkable growth driven by factors such as rapidly increasing use of smartphones; propagation of 4G networks; as well as robust growth in Internet applications. Growing awareness among consumers regarding mobile wallets, and increasing security of mobile payments are the other demand drivers for the mobile wallet market. Increased emphasis on easy and convenient payment modes by consumers also represents one of the market drivers. Mobile wallets are most widely used for mobile commerce. Mobile ticketing and mobile money transfer are the other major application areas. In addition, the introduction of highly developed mobile payment technologies, such as NFC (Near Field Communication), is expected to enhance the mobile payments adoption, as consumer's demand for convenience would be fulfilled by the contactless payment service. Mobile payment market is witnessing rapid growth along with increasing focus on product innovations. While mobile manufacturers seek to differentiate their devices, service providers are launching compatible and efficient mobile payment services for customers. The concept of mobile wallet is becoming popular since customers are being encouraged to use mobile handset as a cashless payment option. With advanced security and convenience, users are opting for m-payments for high-value purchases. The promising outlook is fueling significant competition among existing players as they look for new strategies to gain an edge over competitors and strengthen relationship with customers. The increasing sophistication of mobile devices is also prompting both established and new players in the market to offer advanced, dedicated mobile payment solutions and easy-to-use applications.


Global Efforts to Go Cashless Instigates Broad-based Opportunities

Cash is increasingly becoming obsolete as IT makes a revolutionizing entry into the retail banking sector. Personal checks and hard currency are becoming less popular, while increasing investments in FinTech solutions have pushed up innovations such as PayPal, Square, Apple Pay and cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin, thereby boosting the cashless age. Contactless card payments have made even smaller value transactions/payments faster and easier. Other major factors driving the world towards a cashless society include launch of chip and pin payment cards, broadening ecosystem of smartphone payments apps, convergence of finance, banking and telecommunications, and rapid changes in custom, culture and regulations elicited by Internet technologies, strong penetration of Internet enabled smartphones etc. Strong venture capital funding of financial technology start-ups and their commercial innovations are disrupting the status quo held by cash. Stringent regulations and policies and sops such as reduction in value-added tax (VAT) rates on card payments are additionally encouraging the evolution of cashless societies. Several countries are already witnessing the gradual death of cash such as Netherlands where cash is no longer accepted, while few others are strategically executing economic and financial policies aimed at deliberately reducing the amount of physical cash circulating in the economy such as India, Nigeria (Cash-less Nigeria Project), among others. A key reason for the regulatory clampdown on cash in developing countries is the growing burden of cash usage such as costs associated for handling the cash i.e. paper currency printing, deployment/maintenance of ATMs, high risk of money laundering, higher ability to manipulate cash transactions for tax avoidance, breeding of large unorganized sectors that create “shadow economies” that make no contribution to a economy’s GDP growth, inability of the government to impose fiscal controls, reduced productivity of the banking sector in terms of foregone interest, reduced corporate dividends, high counterfeiting costs, among others. Electronic channels in comparison provide a clear and transparent audit trail. For instance, in Nigeria where cash transactions dominate to almost 100% of all financial transactions, the creation of a shadow economy is massive standing at approximately 65% of GDP. In countries such as France, Turkey, Greece, Italy, Sweden, Norway and the Netherlands, receipts are made mandatory for cash transactions thereby discouraging cash payments. In conclusion, cash payment regulations and the ensuing forced development of infrastructure for electronic payments and optimization of hitherto underused electronic infrastructure, will continue to act as a catalyst for the growth of digital banking market. Cashless societies indirectly promote remote banking activities, which is a special value for emerging countries where standing in queue to carry out banking transactions is common and widespread.


EXHIBIT: Global Non-Cash Transactions in Billion by Geographic Region for the Years 2016 and 2020
Region 2016 2020
North America 148.6 184.5
Europe 99.9 140.0
Asia-Pacific 116.7 257.6
Central Europe, Middle East & Africa 50.6 94.4
Latin America 40.1 43.6
Total 455.9 720.1


The Rise of Customer Self-Service Tilts Digital Banking Technologies into the Mass Adoption Stage

The customer service landscape is rapidly changing with technology developments and ever-growing customer expectations ushering in a new era of self-service customer services. Defined as automation of routine assistive services including billing and payments, customer service automation plays a major role in relieving the burden of customer care administration. In an economic climate where there is constant downward pressure on support budgets, customer service automation offers numerous benefits to manufacturing and service oriented companies. Most importantly, by automating customer service processes companies can focus time, resources and staff on other core operations of business value. Automated customer care enables companies to meet the ever growing customer service expectations and streamlines communications between brands and consumers. Also, with technology developments and rise of connected customers, a growing number of customers prefer customer self-service, also known as e-support. The future of customer service lies in the self-service infrastructure since self-care & provisioning system offer dual benefits to both the customer and the company. While for companies/service providers, the architecture allows for a significant reduction in customer management costs, for customers it offers the flexibility to manage their accounts, payments, orders and consumption patterns. Key benefits accrued to service providers include reduced administration and management costs, and increased customer satisfaction, loyalty, and retention rate by personalizing customer experience. Companies are therefore empowering customers with personalized self-service and in the process are also utilizing these self-service portals into brand differentiators in the market.


Rapid Growth in eCommerce and mCommerce Spurs Consumer Appetite for Digital Banking

The global eCommerce sector has been witnessing robust growth over the past several years, led by continuous advancements in Internet speed and bandwidth, and proliferation of smartphones and the use of the same for online shopping and banking. A bulk of eCommerce growth is forecast to come from developing countries in Asia-Pacific supported by increased spending among existing digital buyers; rapidly digitalizing lifestyles especially of the growing base of affluent middle class population; growing popularity and acceptance of mobile commerce (mCommerce), and rise in the number of SMBs foraying into the eCommerce space given the ability of eCommerce platforms to enable targeting a wider and more global customer audience than is possible with traditional methods. Another major factor driving robust growth in eCommerce is the rapid expansion of a wide range from products and services being traded and marketed over the eCommerce platform i.e. apparels, electronics, groceries, consumers durables to automobiles. The development of mobile wallets or digital wallets has revolutionized the payment industry, ushered in the era of cashless societies, and has given eCommerce a major boost. The ease of payments offered by mobile wallets has helped double the volume of online B2C retail transactions. Also benefiting the growth of the eCommerce are technologies such as Person-to-Person payments, SIM-based debit & credit cards, Near Field communication (NFC) based transactions, and alternative payment networks. eCommerce market in China is poised to grow bigger than the established markets supported by the expanding base of affluent middle class population in the country. Few of the major drivers responsible for the explosive growth in developing countries include ease of paying online, rise in Internet broadband penetration and mobile Internet subscriptions, growing GDP per capita, strong smartphone and tablet penetration rates, expansion in online product choices and reduction in physical product delivery time, among others. E-Commerce has played a pivotal role in pushing up the popularity of electronic payment modes such as credit cards, debit cards, smart cards, e-money, and electronic fund transfer (EFT). Banking enterprise strategies help e-Retailers to drive down costs, increase profits, boost customer satisfaction, retain customers, and reduce churn. A key benefit offered by digital banking is transparency as customers can review even historical transactional data without depending on a call center or visiting a bank branch.

AI & ML Come to the Fore to Reinforce Digital Banking Ecosystem

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) are increasingly being emphasized in digital banking environments to further streamline and simplify the digital banking operations. AI empowers the digital banking tools with the ability to resolve extremely complex problems by way of drastically increasing efficiency. Already, quite a few major banking & financial services firms from across the world have deployed AI along with other advanced technologies such as neural networks, machine learning, evolutionary algorithms and big data analytics among others, for crunching massive loads of and varied, deep and diverse datasets. In addition to helping in operations, these novel technologies hold the potential to bring back the long lost personal connection that financial companies used to have with their customers. In the early banking years for example, employees at the bank built personal connections with customers and assisted them in making investment related decisions. However, over the years, with technologies creeping in, human connection has declined gradually. Customers today do not visit banks unless there is a major banking task to be completed. However, AI and other technologies are touted as being capable of bringing back the human touch to banking. Bankers can leverage machine learning and AI for using information and data and offer personalized services and products to customers for greater levels of customer satisfaction.

Following are some of the most probable applications of AI and ML in the digital banking ecosystem include:

Decision Making: AI can make possible data driven decision making. Machines analyze data and make better interpretations, enabling bankers to make right decisions.

Automation of Customer Support: AI and other technologies-based customer facing systems such as chatbots, voice systems and text chats can render a human-like service and expert advice to customers.

Claims Management: Insurance companies can utilize machine learning (ML) techniques for better handling of claims. The techniques can accelerate processing time for claims and also reduce handling costs, thus enhancing customer experience. ML algorithms can also scout for data patterns for recognizing past fraudulent claims.

Fraud Detection: Analytics tools are capable of gathering data for conviction and also analyze and interpret it with higher levels of accuracy. AI tools in particular can monitor and learn from behavioral patterns of customers for identifying any deviations and probable fraud incidences.

Insurance Management: AI systems can also be of great use in insurance management. The systems are capable of fully automating the process of underwriting and allow usage of more raw information for better decision making. AI-powered automated insurance agents assist customers online in accurately determining their insurance needs. Data can be employed for better detection of risks and reduce chances of damages for both insured and insurer. Automatic underwriting is also capable of identifying tests that are unnecessary for the insured by linking related datasets, sometimes even external data not existing in medical records.

Fully Automatic Financial Planners and Assistants: Also known as Robo Advisors, these are virtual financial planners and assistants, which help customers in making better financial decisions, in accordance with their personal portfolios and financial goals. Customers obtain the best recommendations when it comes to buying and selling stocks and bonds. All well-established financial organizations and also Fintech startups are currently offering these virtual assistants to their customers.

Predictive Analysis: AI and other advanced technologies can offer predictive analysis for financial service companies. Such analysis is critical for enhancement of sales and revenues and also for resource optimization. Often times such predictions when proven right can be a major turning point, improving business operations and enhancing internal processes, and hence are critical for standing out amidst the intense competition. Massive loads of data are analyzed using advanced statistical techniques such as machine learning and data mining for identifying patterns and predicting insights. The insights predict what would happen next for instance, what a customer would buy or how long an employee might last in an organization. Predictive analysis also has the ability to assess credit scores of customers. This helps financial companies avoid bad loans.

Wealth Management Solutions: AI can also be used for offering advisory services for wealth management to low-net worth market segments. AI-based smart wallets for example can be used for monitoring and learning customers’ behavior. Based on the analysis of data pertaining to their actions, customers can be instructed to change spending habits or restrain from spending.

Going forwards, the global financial industry is expected to move towards complete automation through the use of advanced technologies such as AI. AI, along with chatbots and machine learning, has the potential to significantly expand skills, reduce costs and enhance customer experience for financial companies. However, for leveraging the technologies fully, Fintech companies are required to work in collaboration with developers, coders and designers for better identification of new problems and for devising best solutions for those problems.


Millennials: Key Demographic Steering Adoption of Digital Banking

Digital banking continues to gain traction among the Millennial population, who are more inclined towards online transactions and ecommerce because of their household and personal needs and higher purchasing power. Millennials are found to be more tech savvy and leverage digital technologies including mobile wallets and online banking portals as a more appropriate way to make banking transactions, pay utility and other bills, and also to view, access and purchase products they are interested in. With a population size of around 75 million in the US, and a purchasing power of US$200 billion, millennials are emerging as a powerful demographic. They are also considered as the truly “mobile first” generation, as they grew up in internet connected world. They are cost-conscious as well, because they grew up in the worst recession period. Millennials are likely to adopt the technology early by five times more, hence can be either consumers or drivers. Per month they spend around 96 hours on social networking sites, and about 45% of them spend an hour daily shopping online, with two people out of three purchasing products using mobile devices. However, to tap and sustain such important demographic successfully, marketers need to focus on certain terms and user behavior.


Growing Focus on Environmental Sustainability to Benefit Digital Banking

Due to its versatility, cost-effectiveness, and flexibility, digital banking is increasingly adopted by consumers as well as businesses. Since digital banking enables companies to cut down on expenditure of printing bill invoices, postage and dispatch, it is expected to significantly reduce the growing demand for printing paper, postage and envelopes and in turn save trees and conserve forests. Deforestation and species loss are major fallouts of increased consumption of paper and forest products. Paper therefore carries environmental costs as paper manufacturing requires natural resources such as trees, water, and energy. With growing number of banks as well as commercial enterprises voluntarily undertaking the role of environmental stewardship, the ensuing emphasis on paperless office is benefiting the market for digital banking. A majority of commercial enterprises are migrating to a paperless work environment as an effective alternative to the expensive option of developing on-premise enterprise infrastructure for storage of paper based files and documents. Digitizing paper yields significant benefits including reducing costs associated with distribution, streamlining business processes, enhanced customer service, and eliminating the need to physically store huge volumes of information. Going paperless offers significant cost savings, facilitates better customer service, aids in complying with regulations and ensuring business continuity in an event of disaster. Although the initial costs of going paperless are high, the long term savings it enables in the form of lesser printer paper and copier costs outweigh the upfront costs involved. Furthermore, digitizing paper also enables secure and faster way to access information thereby reducing the service time and enhancing the quality of service provided to customers. Against this backdrop of benefits of going paperless, SMBs, are increasingly adopting the initiative to achieve cost savings and enhance operational efficiencies. Poised to gain under this scenario are digital banking solutions payment tools, processing services, customer & channel management, and risk management, among others.


Developments in Internet Security: Primary Compulsion for Market Expansion

While the Internet offers numerous advantages and empowers mankind in general and enterprises in particular, it also brings in its fair share of challenges and perils. The unconventional challenges created by the increasing reliance of companies, governments, and people on the Internet have brought to the fore threats posed by malware, spyware, spam, spoofing, phishing, botnets, unauthorized data leakages and access to confidential information networks and identity thefts, among others. Also, improved bandwidth connectivity and high-speed inter-office communications led to a rise in the sophistication of potentially unwanted programs (PUPs) such as spyware. High speed of broadband connectivity enables PUPs to automatically install itself on a target PC or come hidden or bundled in some other form of software that the unsuspecting user downloads from the Internet. In some cases, even before the user suspects security violation, PUPs intercept and copy private banking details and get access to confidential user information. The vulnerability of the Internet to these aforementioned security threats weakens the business case for digital banking. Growing use of computer networks, easy availability of hacking software, increasing use of Internet for online financial transactions, including funds transfer and online shopping, rising number of Internet downloads and increasing ability of network infrastructure to support multiple users and services will continue to expose Internet users to a range of security threats. Financial transactions especially are vulnerable with the increase in data-stealing malware that steals proprietary information including credit card numbers, passwords, social security numbers, bank credentials and other important information from compromised PCs and networks.

Against the backdrop of the ever-present threat to Internet and cyber security, strong emphasis is being shed on Internet security technologies. To ensure integrity, authenticity and confidentiality of information exchanged over the Internet, several advanced information security hardware and software products have been developed over the years. From cryptography, public key infrastructure (PKI), web single sign-on, legacy authorization, email/web content filtering services, antivirus software, web filtering, firewall/VPN software, intrusion detection/prevention solutions to unified threat management appliances, the Internet security infrastructure has evolved rapidly. With the development of efficient security solutions that can safeguard digital infrastructure, the security stigma associated with conducting online financial transactions is gradually dissipating. With most digital banking platforms now engineered to leave an electronic audit trail, customer confidence is receiving a major boost. Concerns over security of Internet transactions and lack of confidence in secure processing of payment, which until now were major bottlenecks to widespread adoption of the digital banking, are now easing. With the number of Internet connected households increasing, online banking is steadily on the rise supported by incremental improvements in Internet stability, reliability and security. Developments in Internet security technologies are therefore helping reduce the number of technology drifters and financial technophobia among prospective customers wary of going online.


4. GLOBAL MARKET PERSPECTIVE

MARKET ANALYSIS

UNITED STATES


The United States: Major Market for Digital Banking Technologies

The United States constitutes the single largest market for digital banking technologies, representing about 29% share of worldwide revenues. Due to the meteoric rise of Internet and mobile device eco-system, digital banking is gaining traction among consumers across the board. American banking entities operating in retail, corporate, and investment banking domains are increasingly relying on digital banking platforms to ensure smoother, flexible, transparent and efficient services to their clients. Different types of digital banking solutions for payments, processing services, customer & channel management, and risk management, are increasingly being deployed by the American banking entities. Cloud-based tools (BaaS & BaaP), White Label Banking, and Chatbots are some of the technology solutions gaining traction in the US digital banking domain.
